name: enrich
content:
enrich verb
(IMPROVE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
C1 [ T ] to improve the quality of something by adding something else: Fertilizer helps to enrich the soil. My life was greatly enriched by knowing her.
More examplesFewer examplesThese trips give students the opportunity to enrich their independent studies in geography and history.The presentations could be enriched with more digital media.Her work enriches our view of the 1960s.

enrich verb
(GIVE MORE MONEY)
[ T ] to make something or someone richer: enrich yourself He claimed that the large stores were enriching themselves at the expense of their customers.
More examplesFewer examplesThe government's economic policies are designed to enrich insiders.The reforms will not benefit ordinary people but simply enrich law firms.Unfortunately, other attorneys act like predators, exploiting patients and physicians to enrich themselves.

enrich verb
(ELEMENT)
to increase the level of a particular isotope (= one form of an atom) in an element in order to make it more powerful or make it explode more powerfully: The country disclosed in 1984 that it could enrich uranium for nuclear weapons.
More examplesFewer examplesHe was a metallurgist employed by a European consortium that enriched uranium for nuclear power. Facilities housing plutonium and enriched uranium were often poorly guarded.Nobody knows when the regime will have enriched enough uranium for a bomb.He came forward with allegations that the government was enriching uranium at a secret site.
